children.value: Open up your favorite code editor to start setting stuff up.

Dealing with images on the web has always been an issue. You have to have the right sizes, you have to have the right formats, if something is too big, it will load slowly, etc. Luckily, Gatsby built a plugin to handle images elegantly called

. Using Gatsby’s GraphQL queries, you can request different sizes, formats and have a few options as to how you want to handle the image load. For this tutorial you’ll be using a blur up approach, similar to how Medium handles their images.
file in the pages folder, you’ll see there is an
You’ll put all of the images in a folder inside
or use your own, just make sure to follow a similar format). Then, you’ll edit the
file to expose that folder to a GraphQL query.
Add that under the existing filesystem config and then restart your Gatsby server (I believe it’s necessary for it to build the query before calling it).
Now that you have configured the filesystem, go ahead and create a component that will request all the images with a GraphQL query.
component is using a render prop where it’s returning your
component. For now, it’s a simple component inside
By now, you should have all the images displaying on the home page and doing a fade-up load.
For styling, you’re going to be using
. To get it configured with Gatsby, run the following inside your terminal in your application:
Lets restart the application to make sure the config has taken its effect. Now, you’re going to create a simple
styled component to wrap your images in. Your
component should look like this now:
Now the page should look something like this:

children.value: Connecting the image click to the Lightbox
Now, you’re going to convert each
component into a button that you can click that will trigger the lightbox to open up with the right image selected. Here’s how you do that:

if you have any questions, comments, requests or just want to show some ❤️.
